Task.TaskDescription: Problem: Mark enjoys watching obscure, barely known movies so he subscribes to ObscureFlix. He can watch all the movies he wants, although he has to pay $2.5 per movie. However, the good people at ObscureFlix only have an average of 5 copies of each movie, so they often have to wait for movies to be returned before they can ship them out again. On average ObscureFlix can only ship half of the movies on Mark’s movie queue each week, which of course removes them from the queue. After an initial frenzy where he started up his queue by putting 30 really rare movies on it, the number of movies Mark adds to his queue each week is about 20% of the number of movies already on the queue. Goal: Make a graph that shows how many movies he has in his queue over the space of 12 weeks.
Task.ShortDescription:
The number of movies on the queue at the end of this week = 
 the number of movies on Mark’s queue at the end of the previous week 
 + the number movies Mark adds to the queue this week 
 - the number of movies removed from the queue this week. 
 Initially, the number of movies in the queue is 30. 
The number of movies removed from the queue each week = 
 the number of movies on the queue at the beginning of the week 
 - The number of movies shipped to Mark each week. 
The number of movies shipped to Mark each week = 
 the number of movies on the queue at the beginning of the week 
 * The proportion of movies from the queue shipped each week. 
The number of movies Mark adds to the queue each week = 
 the number of movies on the queue at the beginning of the week 
 * the proportion of movies that Mark adds to the queue this week 
The proportion of movies that Marks adds to the queue each week is given as 0.20. 
The proportion of movies from the queue shipped each week is given as 0.5. 
The amount of money Marks spends per movie in dollars is given as 2.5. 
The amount of copies of a movie on average is given as 5. 
The number of movies on the queue initially is given as 30.
